column1: Glossopharyngeal neuralgia is a condition in which there are repeated episodes of severe pain in the tongue, throat, ear, and tonsils, which can last from a few seconds to a few minutes.
Glossopharyngeal neuralgia is believed to be caused by irritation of the ninth cranial nerve, called the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Some possible causes for this type of nerve pain (neuralgia) are: - Blood vessels pressing on the glossopharyngeal nerve - Growths at the base of the skull pressing on the glossopharyngeal nerve - Tumors or infections of the throat and mouth pressing on the glossopharyngeal nerve

Tests may include: - Blood tests (sugar level) to look for the causes of nerve damage - CT scan of the head - MRI of the head - X-rays of the head or neck Sometimes the MRI may show swelling (inflammation) of the glossopharyngeal nerve.
The goal of treatment is to control pain.
Over-the-counter painkillers such as aspirin and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are not very effective for relieving glossopharyngeal neuralgia.
Surgery is considered effective for people who do not benefit from medications.
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of glossopharyngeal neuralgia.
